values:
...Experience is an amazing, wicked, thing.  I've gained it by the bucketful by every little thing that I see or that happens near me or to me, and I move with it.  I have a bad habit of leaning into the touch of things I KNOW will hurt me just because I know it will bring knowledge and greater understanding with it.  Amazingly, it's never gotten me into trouble I couldn't ultimately handle, though I imagine a good part of that is only because of what the experiences taught me even as they crushed.  

   I've never expected other people to do the same.  I've been told I have some frightening and likely damaging coping mechanisms, which would include that leaning into what I know will hurt me because I believe it will ultimately be worth it.  I usually get roped into the idea of doing it for someone else somehow, being some help...  I just get more benefits than everyone else thinks, in my mind.  Just because I'm eager for life lessons doesn't mean I would suggest my methods...  they're mine, and I understand that.  

   So many people think I'll be callous towards their pain from something because I have so much history and day to day experience with it.  I've held people who are crying and trying to APOLOGIZE to me for not holding out, saying how I must think them such babies.  It makes me damn sad that they rarely ever seem to believe me when I tell them that pain is relative, perception, and they're in hell right now, I do understand.  My problems are not theirs, and... well, pain IS entirely relative.  I've often found myself glad that I endured what I did in high school just because it made me capable of handling what became of me once I started off to college, as it multiplied by rabbits.  

   I had shingles this past month and I'm only just finishing the last vestiges of it, and it's something I would never wish on my worst enemies...  I handled it horribly, experience or no.  It's strip-mined the resources I worked so hard to build up after being diagnosed and the fibromyalgia's back in all its glory with a few twists...  And I just broke down when I realized what I was in for, sobbing on the stairs.  I handled putting the damn thing into regression before without meds for it, pure determination and will, drive, a refusal to be beaten down...  But I've been so battered in the past few years by my own damn body's ails that...  It's just too daunting.  I don't want to spend another six months minimum making sure my meals are good and square and frequent in order to push that beast away again.  Not since my diet's been so changed that it's damn hard to get said good down period, let alone being sure of nutritious value.  It might work if I can get the nausea under a better handle because damn to I love to cook from scratch... the kitchen heat just got to be unbearable when the nausea got into full swing, when I was eighteen.  That would be lovely, really...

   I got into the mood to write this though, because I relived an experience after the subject was brought up chatting with a friend... and the details wouldn't leave me.  

   I love people, with all their dreams and loves and faults.  An old friend used to always scorn me in utter confusion because he believed the world was a terrible place and needed to be fixed, and I always returned that I thought it was perfect as was...  Sometimes I have a hard time telling the difference between "good" and "bad" things that happen to people; in my mind, there's no such thing.  An event has an ill or adverse effect on a person entirely based on how they perceive it...  just like how I perceive many of the bad things that happened to me as having been good, and my "leaning into danger" has always been a worthy adventure or endeavor for me, even while I've made my friends shriek warnings before they tried to figure out why I wasn't getting burned.  

   I'm very familiar with seizures, though I use the term loosely.  I refer to my own disorder as "the Twitch" and it's not technically a neurological disorder we think, the more we go along, but a muscle disorder.  Unlike the classic case of seizures you see (grand mal) I do not lose awareness, and so far as we've been able to tell, nothing is firing oddly in my brain when it happens, as with epileptics.  On the other end of the spectrum, my "fits" are significantly more "violent" than most people with honest seizures; I've thrown myself close to two yards on occasion, slam my elbows into my thighs, give myself mass cases of whiplash, and that's when I'm being held on a king-size bed, without anything to hurt myself with.  I've almost flipped desks, been trapped under desks, slammed any part of my body as hard as my strength allows into the furniture and floor.  If there's a way to hurt myself during my fits, I've long found all the methods, though I've been careful to avoid some.  After a while you get enough "experience" as it were to predict and try to counteract the things that will end badly, like getting the hell out of a bathroom if you're lucky enough to feel it coming, shoving the things in your hands or lap to someone else so you make less mess, purposefully trapping your hands in blankets so the movement is slowed and you're less likely to smack someone.  

   I know myself, and I understand what I learn.  It took me years to really understand how horrifying it was to see that same sure knowledge in someone other than myself.  No wonder people crowded and worried, for all that it was my normal, I suppose.  

   I worked at this house that was sort of a step between for delinquent girls between house arrest and jailtime, with a lot of behavior modification program stuff instilled, pretty controlled environment.  Thankfully I was just graveyard staff, but we came on at 10pm and stayed until 8am, and we woke the girls at 6am, so there was some interaction.  

   We'd had one of the girls on watch for a while, she was apparently having seizures increasingly often, as of yet undiagnosed but they were working on it.  I'd seen some of the other girls getting under her shoulders and helping her walk when she looked dead tired, and how she was allowed on the couch hat normally they were restricted fro and let to sleep which was another rule...  And I remembered seeing some of the other staff look irritated, like they knew they were being scammed but had to tolerate it, and some of the girls with bits of jealousy and malice, even as so many girls were dead concerned.  I wasn't sure how much was genuine and how much put on because I was used to the manipulation games the girls thought they were subtle with by then...  

   I knew that weary bite of waiting to be told to stop misbehaving when I curiously asked her how long they lasted, how often they happened, because the staff seemed to be torn on what to believe, and I believe that every angle is worthwhile.  It's why I love people so much... it's all perception games and the truth has so many facets it'll keep me playing with it like a puzzle game for hours if not weeks.  I stayed neutral and empathetic, and made sure she understood hat I wasn't looking for more than an answer, and she explained what she had been told of when and how long because she wasn't conscious for it... that she only felt the pain and exhaustion afterwards.  

   I never lose awareness during mine, not unless I manage to fall asleep truly (which takes some real damn exhaustion, let me say), but I knew exactly what she meant by the exhaustion.  I had never had someone try to practically carry me the way her friends were catering to her, largely because it would have made me feel worthless, with my personality, but I could SEE that exhaustion and how she was trying to cope by doing her best not to care that some people thought she was making it out to be more than it was...  Hell, the poor girl didn't even know when it was happening, she just got the backlash, the bruises and the muscle pain and that deep, deep bone-weary exhaustion.  Your muscles were never meant to move that way, not regularly, not more than a handful of times a month and rarely together; we're not built for that abuse, so it hurts and it tires more than one would think given the amount of motion actually involved, especially with the normal types, not me.  If someone sees me in a fit they KNOW how much it costs, the motions are so exaggerated with mine and you can just see the power it takes to do them, but the ones so many can perceive as a kind of shakes?  It can be hard for people to get their heads around.  

   Unless you've experienced or tried to hold someone, or you've seen similar enough, or understand anatomy enough to see how purely unnatural the motion is, it can be very hard to comprehend the work involved.  The motions are normally so small because the muscle is already wound and constrained so tightly that they're not capable of moving more than that, even though they're doing their damndest.  As best as i can figure, mine are such big motions because mine isn't an electrical impulse gone wrong, it's that something has been slowly building tension in my muscles and they finally reached breaking point, where they could either seize to release tension or cramp, twist, and lock down on themselves.  My "seizing" is a reaction, a good, helpful one even, not the problem itself, and so in doing it, my muscles regain some of their power and... yeah, more power to fight back what's hurting them, with me in the middle.  

   I don't even remember her name...  I can think of five names, one of which I know was hers, but I've forgotten it now, for all that I'll never forget her face, how she looked and how I tried to ease her pain as much as I could that morning.  I wonder if she remembers my name...  I never actually filed the report I was supposed to on the incident, I figured there were so many witnesses that I didn't want to relive it, especially after they TAPED part of it...  I wonder if she even knows it was me who took care of her those two hours, refusing to leave her side, when the poor thing had only had a fit for up to iftten minutes before, if memory serves, even if they'd been somewhat frequent.  I was the only staff with a fucking clue of how to treat her properly, I swear to God...  

   The girls had a max amount of time for their showers and chores in the morning, the ones that shower in the morning instead of at night.  The girl with the seizures, we suddenly realized one morning, was behind, no one had been in that bathroom for a while, cleaning they did every morning behind schedule.  One of the sweeter girl came for us when she couldn't get the door open, and the other girl wasn't responding.  We did a search; she wasn't anywhere else in the house.  

   She was trapped in that tiny closet of a tub and toilet.  

   It took some maneuvering for me to get in, since I was the smallest and most flexible of the people working that morning, and I managed to mover her enough that we could get the door open.  She'd had aura's of some sort because she'd obviously prepared in whatever little time she'd had.  Her head was on a towel on the ground near the tub but not too close, and her legs half wrapped around one side of the toilet in enough of a way that she kept them trapped there ever as the rest of her shook and writhed; it had been her knees holding the door in place.  Before the toilet was put in, there was maybe 4x4 square feet of space on the floor, s like I said, tiny closet of a space.  

   Possibly the worst place to have a fit that I have ever seen, even more than being trapped on a tile floor against a wall under a metal and glass desk.  At least I was aware during mine and had some means of protecting my head, even if it was just cradling it with both my arms and sobbing because that made the whiplash harsher.  She was fully dressed, and I had to wonder why she hadn't bolted from the bathroom as soon as she felt it, or had she wasted her time dressing instead?  Or had she already been dressed and didn't want to face the humiliation, and instead risked her skull against the porcelain in a fit of pride?  

   Hell, I'd done stupid shit for my pride before, though my self-preservation usually kicked in before I could get too deep, and my pride is a pretty malleable creature, more than most people's, at least.  or had it been that with the auras coming on, she simply hadn't thought of it and went with the only immediate thought that came to mind: "I need to protect my head from this tub, and I've got a towel."

   A lot of things bothered me at the time; I was doing my damndest to both protect her form hurting herself with all the hard surfaces around and untwist her from the appliances enough to get her somewhere safer.  t first I didn't even bother with that, didn't bother with getting the door more open to let in Vicky to help me, assuming that this might be short-lived, maybe even on the tale end of a fit considering how long she'd been unaccounted for.  Trying to twist her out from her surroundings was like to hurt her and it WOULD take her a lot closer from the tub and wall she'd managed to keep as much distance from as she could somehow, and I hoped at first that I wouldn't have to risk it.  

   Looking back, through my "danger mode" thought frame, the thing that twists me deep inside that I mostly took as a good sign then is what got me on this tirade.  She understood what was happening to TRAP her legs, like I will mine, she understood that her safety alone rested not most in the towel for padding but in keeping her body from being CAPABLE of flinging her too hard into hard things.  

   Experience teaches...  I ought to know.  As I said, while I never considered too deeply what others honestly thought after knowing I'd been outcast and would be stared at whenever I twitched, it was something else entirely to see someone else go through the same thing, with that same tried and true teacher that liked to make or break you.  However much I like my method of learning some days, I would never wish to inflict on anyone what they don't want.  I am grateful for the lessons my twitch brought me in the long run, but I never wanted it; it was simply my lot in life.  

   I wanted to protect her more than anything, no matter what I had to do.  

   This wasn't exactly a new emotion for me... it's what I've always done, even as a small child.  I am also very clinical in my frame of mind when I see danger lurking, very analytical and cool, but I just UNDERSTOOD to such a degree...  and I wanted to keep her from hurting anymore than she already would from the motions themselves when she came back to herself.  I've always had that kind of heart, but it...  

   What really made it so poignant, in part, was when I finally let Vicky in to help, when I realized that this wasn't going to pass quickly enough for the bathroom's risks to be less than rising injury untangling her in such a small space was Vicky.  I was afraid she would get more power if she had her legs and I wasn't disappointed; most of my powerful ones come from when it comes through my lower back and hips, the lower body is just so much stronger.  I used body body as a constant cushion, barrier, and brace to keep her movement minimal until we got her straight enough that we could get her carried out, and that took a while...  I definitely got my share of bruises, and my arthritis was SCREAMING, but I hardly cared.  The position we ended up in for a while, because once we got her legs free they curled and it was almost impossible to get the door open again, was with my right knee boring down on her shoulder next to her neck to keep her from getting closer to the tub, right hand loosely over the top of her crown and behind her head, to take in the shock when she went up and to prove another barrier if she turned out more lie me than I though and surprised me with something stronger than usual and went into the tub anyway; she DID surprise me a few more times, more power than I thought she had in her by then.  My lower left leg was snugged against her ribs to keep her from moving too much my way, tightly held with enough cush from my calf that it shouldn't hurt her, and I was trying to direct Vicky on how to hold her other side, as her side and arm and hips were still thrashing rather well and while I was trying to hold that too, I've only got so much body to work with and restrain a young teenager without the restraint hurting her in the end.  

  I don't really blame Vicky, and I didn't then, for all that I was frustrated beyond all means with her.  She was in a brand new situation, I could tell she was nervous, and it was like she couldn't understand what I was trying to tell and show her what to do.  She made more general grab and hold attempts that won't work half as well and were more likely to hurt them both if the girl moved hard and unexpectedly.  She didn't understand how close she needed to be, to make her body into a buffer and that if she did it correctly, working as that buffer would not, COULD NOT hurt her because the idea was to also take away the girl's leverage.  Maybe she was more affected than I realized, looking back... maybe I was rambling and expecting her to understand a train of logic that is mostly just native to me; I've been known for that one extensively my whole life, it's always been what, along with my good grades and happy nature, eventually ended up with me labeled as the harmless, brainy eccentric.  

   In any case, her lack of understanding drove the stake of how important this was to me deeper, drove it into me how much I understood because of what I had been through where maybe others just couldn't follow sometimes...  Made me realize that however much I love to dive into the unknown, I was damn glad that others rarely followed me, that they DID dismiss me as the eccentric and left me to my devices.  I understood this girl's pain more than she would ever really know, wanted to protect and care for her all I could even though she was little more than a stranger, and it quickly became evident that I was the only one who had a clue as to HOW to protect her.  I shifted so that I kept my right knee to her shoulder but instead sat on my butt against her left side and spread my left leg over her body to snug my foot against her right side, pinned her arm against her chest with my left hand and used the girl as my base of balance, exerted more strength to keep her still without enough to hurt her, and told Vicky to just focus on getting the door open again.  My arthritis in my hips and knees absolutely hated me, especially with the extra strength I had to use, but as before, I didn't really care much; it wasn't relevant.  

   Once we got her out into the room outside, a bedroom, I had everyone fetch pillows to work as I had been just using me and kept watch over her, though most of the fight had gone out of her already, few powerful moves left.  At the same time, she didn't stop for... for hours, it seemed like, and I know it was in reality at leas ninety minutes, but maybe over two hours; I can't remember anymore.  For the most part I just sat on the floor by her, talking incase she could hear me, carding my fingers through her hair for until after nine-thirty...  I refused to leave until it had mostly passed, and no one argued with me on it.  Then it was home to sleep for the day and be ready to come back to work at night, and for the most part nothing was ever said about it again.  

   I just...  I noted a part of this story to a friend earlier and the emotions hit again like a freight train, refusing to let me loose until I had relived it all again, almost making me cry.  She was helpless, and I could do so little, yet it was so much more than everyone else, apparently.  I never would have thought that someone else might not have been able to do it, even though I've had so many people try to help me in my fits and it's only recently that I've found any method tolerable.  I always assumed I couldn't be helped other than maybe getting me somewhere where there were less surroundings to hurt myself with.  I assumed I was always alone, and it was frightening, but... it was what it was, I thought.  I didn't want anyone to even try helping me because it never actually helped, and then they would either get annoyed or feel terrible for having tried and not done anything worthwhile.

   ...Mari was the first one to change that.  He decided to try to comfort me anyways, even when I warned him not to be hopeful and... even just having a reassuring touch on my back that did nothing for the twitching itself was an amazing comfort.  It didn't technically help, but to not be ALONE...  I suppose that was so much of what sparked my NEED to help that girl as much as I possibly could, what made it mean so much to me when I now I was merely a passing face and I'm fairly sure she remembers nothing from what was likely the worst fit she has still ever experienced.  

   I wish she remembers, to maybe soothe that loneliness, but at the same time, it's alright if she doesn't.  It's never been a particular dream of mine to be some remembered hero...  It's a nice thought, and I don't mind when it does happen, but I don't go out of my way to help however I can for the sake of being recognized or something.  I just...  I think I would feel hollow inside, if I hadn't, you know?  I HAVE to try to help whoever I can... why else would I be here, wish a will and a want and the ability to, if this isn't what I was meant for?  It's what feeds my soul sometimes, I swear, whether it's by holding that girl when she had no defenses or covering for a friend when they could use help with an errand, to maybe saving someone in an ambulance to writing my stories and giving out entertainment that so many, myself included, seek out as an escape and relief from life.  

   All that is experience too...  Maybe I balance out what I'm told are stupid decisions with my moments of pure joy and contentment, the same way my pain comes in highs and lows, with little middle ground.  Hell if I know, but I'm more or less satisfied with life, so I'm not sure what's so unhealthy about my habits.

Well, the good news is that it hasn't happened in a little over three years, and is infrequent.  The bad news, however, is that I just had on HELL of a twitch fit... the sobbing helplessly kind, though as least I was on my bed and not trapped in a desk or something (that had to be one of the WORST ones to have ever happened, mostly because I was terrified that a violent enough movement would knock me senseless).  My room is nice and relatively soundproof, which I normally appreciate for reasons I won't list, but I couldn't get my body under enough control to get out of the gate and screens blocking the bedroom from my office area without probably really hurting myself, and my phone was on my desk.  

In retrospect, I should have just screamed bloody murder instead of slowly giving into the sobs that Ammi eventually heard.  It would have gotten the attention I needed a lot faster. 

So Ammi eventually heard me and came to investigate and I imagine I was quite a site, thrashing and sobbing as I was (the fact that I was only wearing a completely open bathrobe and some blankets didn't help either, probably), and did an immediate "Oh shit!" and went running for Mari.  Mari's very practiced at helping me though fits... And some to think of it, I'm prety sure Ammi's never been around when I fit bad enough to sob.  I think I've only done that twice, and she wasn't there for them.  

The scary part was that I already had three soma (damn good muscle relaxers) in my bloodstream and it was STILL that bad. I shudder to think what it might have been without...  Probably a repeat of the worst time ever, in California, when I woke up my parents down the hall sobbing (Mari's narcoleptic and had had a damn long day and had already held me though a fit, I don't blame him for not waking from the cries even if he was next to me).  I black out a few times, for a couple seconds here and there in that one, and it was bead enough painwise that it's acquired that very surreal quality...  I mostly remember my Munna holding me and just moving THOUGH the twitching with me, so I could use her as a backbone instead of my own, and apparently Mari did the same for some of it, and seeing my father standing in the doorway with a look of horror and utter helplessness on his face...  Before that, he's only seen normal running day twitches, that were sometimes in fast succession, but never one of my true "fits."  Sunk the point home, but it figures that the only one he ever saw was the worse I've ever experienced.  

Like I said though, I WAS already on three soma and had had a hot bath and later a hot shower to try to calm the muscles before it happened, and it wasn't that bad, though it's pretty high on the scale to make me sob.  Though, technically, I haven't had regular fits in years, so part of the difficulty was likely that my body is no longer conditioned to handle it.  When I was, say, 15/16, i would have multiple fits through the day and twitch otherwise a fair bit in between, probably amounting up to several hundred a day...  But since I learned to avoid that around turning 17, and I'm now nearing 21, my body just can't take abuse in that fashion anymore.  I feel like a novice, or a pussy, for all that I KNOW it's a good thing that I don't have that conditioning now.  I'm far healthier for the lack of constant involuntary muscle movement, and I'm very thankful for it.  

I really should just scream as loud as I can next time so I get help, though.  Damn pride, or fear of scaring the shit out of someone, or something.  I promised Mari I would, next time.  

So Mari came up and helped hold me so I wouldn't hurt myself so bad...  Still did a bit, mostly on HIM, but he's currently being a man and claiming no pain for the elbow to the ribcage.  In the process of it all, we actually learned a lot about what could and couldn't be predicted about my movements (I can feel the tension building before the more violent ones) and how he could best help me without hurting either of us...  It's not the same as holding down someone in a true seizure.  Their motions are usually small, almost as though they're vibrating, limbs and such moving two inches max (though I've held someone through a seizure where her motions could go up to 4-6 inches, but those were the rare ones among the many smaller).  I, meanwhile, can fling myself across the king size bed with my bigger ones, on the other hand, and otherwise the full length of my arms, head, torso, or legs can and often WILL extend as far as they can go at high speed.  In a switch centering lower in my torso, my hips as a norm do that same fast movement up to two feet forward or bad, and sometimes a good foot to the side in the process, or as a separate movement; my back is the same, and when those happen the rest of my body is jerked along sometimes in completely unpredictable motions.  The bigger ones...  I've done the whole toes on the ground, crown of the head on the ground, with your body a perfect arch in between.  The doing isn't so bad, honestly, but the landing HURTS and knocks all your breath out of you as though you'd been punched in the gut.  It was a running joke in high school that I could hit someone and totally get away with it, though I never did...  Though I did have a tendency to accidentally fling shit around (like pizza across the table at Ammi when I was holding a slice and twitched).  

It felt like 20 minutes, which is thankful for me... it was actually more like three hours, come to find out.  For a few minutes near then end I though I was going into lockdown (Which is an utterly horrific, terrifying experience I never EVER want to experience again; once was more than enough to sufficiently cow me into avoiding it at all costs.  You see, the twitching isn't a problem, it's actually my body's solution to tightening muscles in my back, so that when I lose the strength to twitch, those muscles instead begin to tghten more, crap, twist on themselves, lock down, and then move on to neighboring muscles in the rest of your body.  All your muscles LOCED into a fetal position is painful as hell because it's far higher tension than causes the twitching in the first place, and trying to move anyway makes it scream more... as you slightly find yourself curling back into the fetal anyhow.  As I said, once was more than enough, if I see the start signs and I do whatever necessary to run like a screaming child.).  Anyhow, I was on FIVE soma at that point (Mari medicated me to try stopping it early on, and I've have done it once it started but the soma was by my phone, same problem) and there's far too many cases of people overdosing from taking six to consider it.  Granted, they took it in much faster succession and probably had a lower tolerance, but the last thing we needed to top the night off was overdose.  We also considered my painkillers to knock me out faster if I started lockdown, but while at lower doses the interaction between soma and opiates is negligible, at a high dose of the relaxer, it might be risky.  

So Mari babysat me in the bath instead.  It sounds funny to say, and I think I'd have been fine, but you NEVER let someone with that many drugs in their system, especially MUSCLE RELAXERS, in a body of water unsupervised.  I pointed out that I know warning signs enough to know to at least get out of the tub fast and stay on the floor if I had to, but he had a point about the dissociative qualities of soma and the chance that I might not notice if it were happening until too late.  

Mari messaged Kye while she was still on what was happening so I hadn't just completely disappeared, and I'll talk to her tomorrow, but I wish that I could have told Ammi when I got better (lockdown signs were the last of it fading out before the soma finished integrating into my bloodstream); she was already asleep.  Not that I blame her, it was three in the morning by then.  

I think this was a mass buildup of stress and stuff... the last two weeks have been a mild throwback to high school for intensity, and I was worried about it, but now that the body got it OUT through such a fit it's likely to calm so long as I relax more, and my emotional state has calmed dramatically in the last two days, as has the schoolwork load (last week had 4 midterms).  

So... yeah.  I think it should be okay, though I probably really nee to talk to my rheumy and possibly that neuro she wanted to refer me to when I told her this was getting worse on Friday... Was that Really only yesterday?  Hell, I hate to be a bother to her, but this probably fills in to the list of things I should call and discuss with her about because it DOES relate to my health, and she probably WILL send out that referral, and... Well, so long as it's not my old neuro (and it's not because he was pediatric) then it should be okay.  I still want to work out a records transfer, though, but hey, that means talking to his office, not his staff...  Did I mention my old neuro and I were never on vaguely good terms?  Something about me repeatedly more or less telling him to go fuck himself...  Him telling me I can't do things because they're impossible while I'm sitting there not doing them...  him making me more or less comatose for a few weeks, then sleepwalking every other time I was forced back onto his meds...  That or puking my guts out in the middle of class...  We REALLY didn't get along, though parting ways with him the last time was fuckin' hilarious because he seemed like he was on the verge of tears to see someone else had helped me solve the problem pretty completely (Munna's theory was that he wanted to do a paper on me), and he had some sentimental 'future' thing running, though my Da and I both agreed walking out that it felt as though we'd just gotten fired or something.  Good riddance, man...

*sighs* Anyhow, bedtime...  And in the unlikely circumstance that it happens again I'm going to scream, no matter that I sound like a dieing seagull.  Mari's other suggestion was to fling something on the floor hard because his hangout area is directly under the bedroom, but the only thing close enough on hand was Ammi's kitten, and not only would he have not made enough noise but... well, yeah, just not.  That one's against my morals (for all that flinging cats across the house in open spaces isn't) even if Ammi wouldn't kill me for scaring the shit out of her cat.  And if I'd had my cat, he'd have made more noise anyhow...  Still not conducive to thought processing, however amusing it still leaves me with the 'not working' factor... And screaming would be more effective anyhow, I prance about the room like a moron running story ideas through my sull anyhow and sometimes trip or make things fall (I  actually sprained my ankle bad enough to need crutches for a few days doing this) so a loud *bump* might be dismissed anyhow.  

Can You tell I'm exhausted?  Your muscles aren't meant to move that way ever, let alone for hours on end, and it hurts to do, and I'm stoned on soma too, which usually makes me act like mostly insanely tipsy happy drunks to start with.

...Right, I'm sleeping.

The question, I suppose, is 'Will writing this out help?' 

I've been told it's supposed to be relaxing, or something... and I suppose that when I find myself in a tight spot, now and then I do come here, and now and then it, in turn, helps a little.  

A great uncle of mine is dying; I've known this for weeks now, but while we've met, I barely know the man, and can only grieve inasmuch as I would for a stranger, and grieve for the signs I see in my parents.  I am familiar with that sort of thing... after all, who isn't?  We have all known of someone or other who died but we didn't know well, and most of us have at some point seen how badly a death can affect a person they know and love.  

My grandfather had been dying for a few years now...  We realized yesterday that 'might not make it through next winter' was really 'He's suffocating from the inside out, come say goodbye and don't bring the six-year-old, she should never remember him this way'.  I'm half trying to stand firm for my mother's sake as this finally hits home, because I've always been the one to hold her as she screams and sobs because someone has died, be they family member or when she watched the towers fall.  She needs something to keep her grounded, and while my father understands this, he tends to be at a loss for how; understanding other people is only something he came on fairly late in life.  So I'm going back and forth between holding firm because my coping mechanism in large part is to simply make sure everything will still be okay once the storm finishes rocking the boat, and simply bursting into tears because oh God, I knew he was fading but now he really is going to be forever gone.  

I found out late last night, and it was both logical, because I knew it would happen eventually, but surreal, because it wouldn't hit home.  Today it was the same until I had to explain to a teacher who knows my father that we were having a mild family emergency, to see if he declines faster I can jump ship and take my midterm later so i can see him one last time... and again I find myself crying, just as I did in said teacher's office this morning.  I felt like a real ass for that, I hadn't meant to cry... though I should have realized I was going to, forcing the idea closer to reality when I knew it hadn't really hit yet.  

I was melancholy after that but it stayed vague until I realized I ought to tell Ammi and Micky, especially if I wanted to see if Micky wouldn't mind hanging out with me at mom's when she wasn't going to be at our house already, since she hates her roommate and so I wouldn't be alone in trying to take care of Jenai while mom's away, until Stephen and I can come up if it really is true that he's going now.  

There's a sliver of a chance he might recover again, but his lung capacity is so damn low that it's asking for a miracle.

Ammi saw it, and I didn't lie that I wasn't good, but wasn't feeling up to talking yet before she came over to try to drag me somewhere more private to talk, because she worries about me when I forget I'm supposed to worry.  It wasn't a secret or anything so I just gathered up my guts to say 'Maynard's dying' before taking my hand back; if I'd let her try to calm me down out of sight right then I'd have gotten deeper in it instead.  The tears snapped out a bit but not as bad that time.  Her face hardened and she asked for what plan we were going with, and offered how it sounded bad but that death was a part of life, but, 'though I know you know that, hell, you're going into medicine' and I agreed.  I've known that for a long time now, and I've known he was dying for the past few years... that doesn't make it stop hurting.  

Mari, Micky and her baby, and I went over to my folks earlier; Munna asked for me to come to dinner and bring whoever, so we could solidify the last few details of what I needed to do while she was away and I think so she could see some friendly faces.  I'd seen her just last Saturday, but...  God, I didn't realize someone could gray like that.  She was perfectly blonde on Saturday, but there's suddenly so much silver in her hair, up on top almost like it was just the sun that did it...  I worry what this is doing to her, and I can't even imagine the wreck I would be if Da died.  I love my grandpa Maynard, but we were never amazingly close... he was just my grandpa, if that makes any sense.  

We have a cat, Tabitha, that's the same age as me, roughly, meaning she's somewhere close to 21, like I will be at the end of the month.  We've thought that cat was dying on us on and off again for years now... for longer than we've known the emphysema was going to kill Maynard, but she kept surprising us, making complete turnaround comebacks.  Ammi likes to call her 'the vampire witch cat' and she and Mari have running jokes about how she's actually a zombie or vampire, living off stolen bits of the creatures around her or something.  She's always been very focused on getting attention, very talkative when trying to get it, and very talkative when being paid any attention, leaning into any touch in typical exaggerated cat fashion.  

Tonight she appeared silently and crawled into Mari's lap before curling up, completely silent, to stay unmoving for the rest of the night, not even protesting when I picked her up and moved her to my lap instead.  It's beyond strange behavior for her, not even reacting to being pet and adored.  She feels lighter than the little chihuahua my folks got Jen for Christmas, and I know that puppy is only a pound or so...  She's all loose skin and bones that feel like they might snap if I move her too fast... I could get four fingers up to my palm under her collar without pulling it tight, it hung so loose on her.  

I'm pretty sure Maynard is going to outlive the cat now, even if he only makes it until Tuesday.  And just sitting there on the couch, holding this ancient, fragile creature I remember finding behind the couch when I was three years old and being delighted, feeling her bones jut against my hands as I try to comfort her and she doesn't respond like she always has, I remember how frail Maynard was when I was saw him, or great grandpa Thatcher a few months before he died, skin drawn tight against a skeleton frame...  I wanted to burst out crying again but didn't because I wouldn't know if I was grieving my grandfather or the cat I've lived with for almost as long as I can remember, and that felt so wrong.  I love my grandfather far more than I could a cat, but she was what suddenly made it so real... to realize that he was just as weak, barely able to get the breath to speak a few words, as the strangely silent calico I felt was about to breathe her last there in my arms.

I'm crying again...  My eyes still hurt from the tattoo and crying makes them ache and burn, but that's well enough...  I'm not sure this helped at all, but maybe my eyes will rest until morning when I end up telling my Rheumy what's going on when she inevitably asks.

Heh, hey... at least the arthritis is doing better than it has in a while.  I always give Chris bad news, it seems, but she seemed so relieved the last few times, that we'd finally worked out how to end the constant pain...  Heh, wholly different kind of pain, the sort she doesn't have to worry about, this time.  If it has to be bad news, at least it's a different variant.

...Or something, anyway.

...How good of a coping mechanism IS staring at the fire in dismay because it doesn't hurt anymore?  I was muttering about the same thing last post, but I'm starting to realize that that is what forms up the core of my personality.  How odd is the logic behind the idea that pain and being burned by other people is a given, and there's absolutely nothing wrong with diving in headfirst knowing this?  

...Exactly when did the fire cease to burn anymore?  I remember when it broke me down every other day to see something that wasn't right and good... and it's not that I don't care now, because I still do whatever I can to help, just... Well, like I said, the pain became a given.  It's all old hat, it's nothing I won't survive.  I'd like to avoid it if all that ought to be done can still be accomplished while doing so, but if not... it's no big deal.  I never expected anything in return from them, so it's not as if I'm let down if it all goes to hell.  

Why is it so shocking when someone is genuinely pleasant in return?  I used to expect it, or at least expect to not be noticed.  When someone I took a liking to seeks me out on their own... is it supposed to be amazing, and light up my whole world?  I mean, I'm not unhappy without that gift... it's beyond nice when I get it, but I do well enough with Mari, Kye, and my parents.  Those four people are the core of my existence... if something goes to hell with them, the world might start to crumble, but I wouldn't hop out on a line any faster for one of them than I would for someone else, because I'm already doing the best I can for total strangers without expecting more than a smile when they realize something in their day didn't go to shit.  It doesn't have to have anything to do with me... and my help isn't anything to do with that unconditional love... it's a given.  I just DO it... and so do my folks, so I guess I learned it from somewhere.  

I love the way someone's eyes sparkle when I do something they like.  That's what life is all about, so is it so bad to avoid things that might not cause that spark when seeing them?  I honestly don't care about the repercussions to me from any successful or failed friendship... what I care about and what worries me is that if I do something to upset them, will anyone else show up that can make their eyes spark?  I like Matt because he makes Ammi's eyes light up, and she deserves that...  My mother would say it differently, but she feels the same.  If she stops wanting anything to do with me again, she won't be miserable like she was so many times before, and that's a DEEP comfort.  I see the same kind of spark in my parent's eyes when I come home, and I love it, it makes me spend far more time than I meant to doing absolutely nothing with them instead of my work.  Maybe it's wrong to try to stir up that sparkle in anyone I meet but... what's the POINT if I don't?  I know some witty comment made by a total stranger can make my day, even if I never see them again.  It's not about the stranger with the comment, it's not about being remembered or any such...  It's just that I like it if I can make someone even just a tiny bit happier somehow.  

I'm not sure if it has anything to do with friendship.  Often enough, that IS how I meet people who become friends, but I'm not actively seeking new people.  If they come, they come, if they don't, I continue happily on with my life.  I don't care either way.  Is this equilibrium the key to happiness?  

I learned the hard way that people don't care to hear me go on and on about something in my head.  It gets you in trouble, because no one believes it's the sheer benevolence you meant it as.  I learned to sick more by the "don't ask, don't tell" philosophy, and it's works.  I can skim topics until I get somewhere they like, and maybe I'll dig up that spark.  I'll mention this or that about me and if they pursue, then maybe it'll be a friendship, or an aquaintance.  If they don't, I won't trouble them with junk they don't give a shit about.  I'm not sure if this idea is self-deprecating or not...  But it makes me more sure that anyone who associates with me gives a damn about whatever topic on some level and I'm not just annoying them.  I mean, me and Kye can go on and on for hours about whatever, but the foundation is already laid down for that equal free-for-all, even if the other doesn't actively care, we still want to know and hear about it if the other noticed... if that makes any sense.  I haven't met anyone else who wouldn't be annoyed by that eventually... Mari likes it on some days to a certain level, and my mother enjoys it when she's got the time, but... yeah.  I suppose that's what best friends are in essence, or something.  

I think Berg believes all the random crap hurts me on a deeper level than I realize, and I'm honestly just curious to know if she's right.  I used to bottle up, but... I don't think I'm bottling up so much as I'm just not taking it seriously.  Maybe I'm a lot healthier than she thinks, and come what may, I'm mostly ready...  but maybe I really am still back at the drawing board.  I suppose I'll find out eventually.  The idea that I might really be clueless and disillusioned isn't upsetting, somehow.  I suppose that's old hat too.  The only arenas where it would really upset me anymore are about those four people I mentioned before, and I'm deep enough with them that I know I'm not wrong there.

Maybe it'll be more than those four people eventually...  I care about so many others, some very deeply, but the entire structure of my existence isn't based off of them.  They could come to hate me and it would be awful, but I wouldn't have to completely scrap what I have and rebuild...  God, I had to scrap and rebuild my psyche how many times before I turned eighteen?  Is the fire not burning anymore just scars?  I never minded scars, to be honest, but I wonder if they are proud marks of experience and lessons learned or just signs of trauma hinting at the damaged final result?  I'm far more inclined to believe the former, but I can't help but wonder if there's truth in the latter.  

I just...  I'm here to enjoy myself, but I'm REALLY alive to help people, I think.  My happiness matters because you can't give what you don't have, and because I'm one of those people who needs that spark too... and looking for it in everyone else helps me find it in me.  I'm still lost and confused, and I imagine I will be for years to come, if not for the rest of my life on some level... and that's okay.  Giving happiness doesn't mean you have to be perfect, and I'm learning that, though perfection in some form or fashion certainly smooths the path.  I'll simply be me... and that's all anyone should ever want of me, or something.

One of these days I'll be more concise in my soul searching and epiphanies.

Life is odd...  Looking back to the path of how we got to today always intrigues me on some level but when I start identifying possible crossroads...  It's not exactly scary, per se, but I will admit to it being unnerving.  

I was muttering about everything to Berg today because she wanted to try to get a better handle on my psyche before we dove into all the Reiki stuff.  Then somehow Kye and I got on the subject of how we came to be friends, and therefore everything with Yira...  How we got here and why, how things might have gone differently, and would might have been currently...  And it hit on some level that I affected Kye's psyche somewhat, not just the other way around.  

It occurs to me that this shouldn't be a new idea, but there you have it.  

Not going to go into details there because that's not my place to say in an entry I'm not going to bother hiding...  just...  All the crossroads, you know?  I don't regret the past, it's those choices and actions that brought me to where I am, and despite all the troubles, I wouldn't trade them for anything.  The pain is worth the rewards brought, just to see a real smile in another person, a genuine appreciation, is enough to go through the fire... and the fire ceased to hurt years ago.  I'm not sure if that means I'm burned down and don't realize it yet, or if it ceased to be a fire when it stopped hurting, but I'm more inclined to believe the latter.  

I'm not sure if it's unhealthy that I automatically expect scorn and dislike from anyone I meet, and that this doesn't bother me in the slightest.  It's something to kinda snort at in amusement and wave a hand to in a dismissive gesture, because it doesn't matter.  I give away whatever might please someone when I can just because I love it when I can get that smile that means their day went a bit better than it otherwise might have, and I don't expect anything back.  It's kinda surprising when I do get something back... I really have no idea what I'm supposed to do with that.  

So... I'm a people pleaser without benefits?  I mean, I get them sometimes, but the only person I'd expect benefits from would be, like, Mari, and that's not even vaguely in the same light.  

Berg says I give everything away too easy... she's worried about the worn down aspect, and she has something of a point.  I'm rather improved from the whipping boy I used to be, but I'll readily admit I haven't worked out all the kinks yet.  I refuse to put up with the absolute shit I would have taken without batting a lash when I was younger... I avoid instances where it might happen in a regular kind of way, but even so, the idea that I might be hurt from someone lashing out at me in the same way is... deeply amusing.  It just... wouldn't hit home, kind of thing, and it's always kinda sad and funny to see someone trying so hard to be vicious when it's completely ineffectual.  

I wear my heart on my sleeve and open up to whoever cares to look... Sassy called it transparency, or something, and the idea of doing it terrifies most people because they see it as pure vulnerability... while it's more along the lines of safety in my mind, because you just make it so there's nothing worth hiding.  It's all been done, kind of thing... I honestly don't think someone could hurt me emotionally anymore.  Not in any serious kind of way, anyhow.  There's always pain on some level, but the kind that can cause you to break down...  That's not a risk from anyone but Mari or Kye, and that's not really a threat.  There's something about having had the people closest to you damn you and take you back over and over again that just makes you stop caring about if you're ditched or not, because it quit being the end of the world after the twentieth time it happened.  Everything's kinda anticlimactic after being spurned so many times even to the point of utter alienation, after so much physical pain to boot, so that you just kinda roll your eyes and go back to what you were doing because there's submitting to what emotions someone expects when they hurt you just isn't worth the time and effort.  It's not going to change anyone's opinion of you, it's not going to change what happened, so keep your notes on not getting into that situation or making an ill choice that caused it again, and move on, because no one else cares what you think, so why bother brooding?  

I'm not suggesting other people take up this mindframe.... just noting that it's become my own.  I'm curious as to how much of it Berg thinks is inappropriate and wants to teach me out of.  I think she believes I'm worse off than I am, and do admit that there's a chance she's right, but I doubt she realizes how much progress I HAVE made in the process of coping.  It'll become more clear for both of us the deeper we go, so it's little more than idle curiosity, excitement as to what will get dug up... and kinda pleasant to have a different opinion on it by someone with training, instead of my shot in the dark method.  

Unconditional love...  Kye has a point abut how that's the key to good relationships.  I kinda throw it out to anyone I come close to, and it makes me sad when I come across those who say I understand them better than any of their friends, because I really DON'T know them when they say it like that.  It makes me sad when someone is so hungry for it because it hasn't been given consistently, but I learned the hard way that I need to stay passive in a relationship and let them take as much as they want before seeing if they want what's attached.  No one appreciates a random mother hen; you have to either earn your rights to be thought of even in passing, or step in and give everything you want to before dashing back out before they're over the shock.  Leave the option of being found if they decide they want to find you, be ready to step in again if you think it might be necessary again... but I don't make the moves for a closer relationship until I'm sought, anymore.  If you care too much, you are assumed to have ulterior motives, and in the end will cause more harm than good.  Down the line you can let them realize the full extent of the unconditional is there for the taking, and if they like the idea, then you can actually dote as much as you want to...  but very few people enjoy being swept off their feet for no reason, because the idea that there might not be a true reason is foreign... or something.  

I have the good luck that my parents have always been completely unconditional about love.  I also have the same luck about Mari, who I found surprisingly early in life.  And I can't begin to describe how it feels when my mother confides in me how happy she is that I found such a true friend as Kye so early in life, considering the fact that she only recently found the same sort with Brooke (well, recent if the last 6 years count, anyhow).  That's probably why the fire of scorn doesn't seem to exist anymore...  It can all burn down and everything will be okay, because the core is still there.  I'll be affected, of course, but... nothing terrifies me anymore.  Everything has gone to complete shit so many times that it's not upsetting beyond the moment, and even in the moment, it's more annoying than hurtful.  

The wondering over crossroads is more a matter of debating who I would be had Mari not come into my life, had Kye and I had not formed our bond for a variety of different reasons.  Mari has been with me since the beginning of true pain, and Kye came shortly after.  I got them when I had no one very close to me, because of all the fights...  I didn't think I might really be desirable before Mari.  When my health went downhill again and again I was often half convinced he would tire of the trouble I brought...  I suppose I never had that fear by with Kye by the time she and I quit having a pissing contest and started having a friendship, but my relationship with her is of a different nature than with Mari, for all that it's just as meaningful and, in reality, more time-consuming, lmao.  Acceptance of each other despite this or that problem was never questioned, probably just by the nature of how we were before becoming close.  

The death of pride is a hard thing, though... I used to be fairly strong, physically, and I took pride in being able to take full care of myself.  To admit to the one you want to share the rest of your life with that you can't do something so simple as change your clothes or open a jar/bottle by yourself... that's hard.  It's hard to believe anyone would want you when you're disgusted with yourself, even when you KNOW better.  When you try to prove you're fine by taking a walk then you break down crying because you can't make yourself walk the short way back... you have to finish damning yourself before you can begin to consider calling and asking for someone to come find you... especially when you only have a vague idea of where you really are.  

The times when I would scream in pain if he touched me, because the fibro took up residence in my skin and every touch, even from my clothes, BURNED... part of his way of handling it was to take up the role of taking care of me, protecting and comforting me... when suddenly he couldn't even hold me as I sobbed, I was terrified he was going to give up.  When I hit the points where all I could manage to do was sleep and focus on something as all-encompassing and mind-numbing as video games for hours on end, then I woke him up in the middle of the night because I went into a twitch fit and hit him on accident and he'd hold me tight to I couldn't hurt myself...  I'll never forget the night that he and my mother held me as I sobbed wildly, thrashing every which way, blacking out for a couple seconds periodically, knowing on some level that those sounds my mom was making were words but not able to quite put the logic to them... as my father stood in the bedroom door, looking on in horror as he realized there wasn't anything he could do.  ...I think I was apologizing as I was doing it... if I wasn't aloud, I was thinking it, that they were losing the sleep because they had heard me sobbing as I finally lost what was left of my control at 2am.  

On some level I expected Mari to run soon after that, because I wasn't getting better... he had no reason to have to deal with my problems, it wasn't fair.  I remember trying to tell him that it was okay, I wouldn't hold it against him, he was perfectly within his rights, I couldn't promise I would ever be who I had been before pain in every fiber of my being began to define my life...  and him demanding to know if THAT was what I had been brooding about for the past few weeks, and that if I honestly thought he was going to go anywhere then I was a fool.  He always read me for little bits of body language... would take things from me and insist on opening them before I could spend the five minutes trying then following ten trying to make myself ask, would offer to help me stand almost as soon as I bit my lip, realizing that there was no way I could roll my weight so that coming back to my feet wouldn't be incredibly painful.  He would tease me that he never had any qualms whatsoever with helping me undress, then when I pointed out that half of it was that I knew it wasn't THAT painful but I still couldn't make myself DO it, he would note seriously that obviously I COULD do it, but he would rather I didn't HAVE to do something that hurt, if he could solve the problem just by helping...  and eventually asking became less of an ordeal.  He likes to joke that I only keep him around for opening jars, and acts all pouty when I DO open something on my own, chasing me about, whining that I've robbed his life of purpose...  

He has some of the stupidest jokes you'll ever hear, you just want to groan, but he can always make me smile, and he cares... we're different enough that we complement each other well to boot, even while we communicate so well that we don't ever really fight.  We get annoyed with each other and sometimes we need to sit and talk something out, but it's never the stupid shit you see in most couples, my parents included.  He and Kye get along just fine, and that's important too, despite the fact that he came before she did.  Kye and I communicate a bit differently, but it balances out to complement perfectly in a different fashion.  Despite being so far away, she's always there for me, and I try to return the favor... whether it's important or just muttering about our characters while we do mundane tasks from the day to day.  It means absolutely nothing and everything at the same time, if that makes sense...  My mother and I are getting to have the same kind of thing the older I get as she asserts less control over me...

And all it boils down to is love that's given no matter what state any of us are in...  even something as stupid as Laura coming over to play video games at my house while I fall asleep on the couch.  Even if I'm in shit condition, it's the time spent, or even not the time spent, just the consideration of the company and letting the other do whatever they damn well please... and that's really convoluted, but that situation ends in us both kinda doting on each other even though we're not technically spending time together if I'm unconscious.  Laura's one of those few people who never thought I had a bad reason to want to sweep her off her feet and show her the world in the palm of my hand... she just enjoys my company and realizes that I enjoy hers and hat's all there is to it.  I think she finds it amusing that I enjoy trying to please her as much as I do, seeing as we both know she'd be perfectly happy if I did nothing of the sort.  I've developed a similar kind of bond with Ammi now that we're out of high school, though we interact differently because Ammi has seen the world in other lights, she wasn't such a blank slate, the way Laura was when she came to college.  It's nice to have friends who don't get offended or suspicious if I just give things out... I like giving gifts for absolutely no reason, I'm generally ecstatic when I DO have a reason.

I mattered in some small way to many and very much to a few... and that's true, real.  I don't need anything flashy. *looks back at the very long post*  I came on here because I was starting to freak out about hair loss from the meds...  But despite not having muttered about it, I feel better.  It'll probably turn out to be nothing major anyway... and as I told Kyle, I could pull off going with a shaved head. When it comes to your body, so long as you're okay with it, everyone else has to be, or else they're either A) not who they want to be, or B) not worth your time.  *grins*  I'm too happy with myself to not have the attitude I would need.  So... no matter what happens, it's always going to be okay, mm?

Just for the record... nausea sucks.  

It's been getting worse... not that the painkillers aren't merrily feeding it fuel, but it's hard to make a choice between wanting to scream and crawl into bed for the rest of your life due to pain, or if you feel like curling in a fetal position and trying to shovel yogurt and bread without sitting up because if you uncurl, you WILL puke.  Either way, they seem to be either constant or a minimum of thrice daily (that's really a good day) of both symptoms.  Today, I didn't take any painkillers and I was really nauseated...  *considers* ...ten times.  Oh, fun, let's make that eleven, say the devil's name and he appears...  Though I wasn't nauseated as often yesterday, when I had to take two Lortabs to get through the day, though those bouts were much more severe... though I'm proud to say I stayed on my feet and walking for the first two major bouts, which each lasted almost two hours...  I had to hit the floor and curl to try to handle the last, then bolt for the bathroom when I realized the yogurt my mom got me wasn't so hot of an idea while it was still peaking...  Cold towel, ice pack, and about twenty minutes later and I was perfectly fine.  My mom's a sweetheart, she kept getting shit for me, then I actually got her to curl into bed with me until the dogs started trying to join us at around five.  

I'm getting better at forcing through it, of measuring how strong it has to be when it's time to run for a toilet NOW, and how long it can be ignored.  I'm trying really hard to have it not destroy my life, but it's kinda hard to walk and grin like normal when it's getting bad enough that I'm dizzy as fuck.  Is it normal for nausea to make everything seem surreal?  It's getting bad enough that I'm starting to feel like when I had the fentanyl patch slapped on when I'm not on anything... and pain is still an issue often enough that maybe I should reconsider the patches.  I ditched them because after feeling like I was trying to wade through really old jelly instead of plain air for a couple hours, I started throwing up or dry heaving every ten minutes until I took the thing off.  Maybe my tolerance for the nausea wasn't too good then...  I've had a lot more experience now.  If I'm going to be that bad anyhow, I might as well have the pain relief benefits.  And God, it would be so nice to have a patch I change every couple days instead of... shit, I really don't want to count how many pills I have to take every morning.  

The Dr. put me on Avara instead of methotrexate because she thought the latter was causing the nausea...  I think the worsening of nausea means she was wrong.  Methotrexate attacks the purine side of the DNA chain (the A and G bases, for those of you who only took basic biology in high school) in cells that are reproducing quickly, Avara attacks the pyrimidines (T and C) in the same fashion, and for unknown reasons when one version attack causes nausea, the other generally doesn't.  Considering how much worse the nausea got after the switch, I think the methotrexate wasn't what was causing the nausea (although it's incredibly uncommon for methotrexate to NOT cause nausea, but I was on it for something like ten months before the nausea started), the Avara's making me worse... which means I'm probably going back to injecting myself with a cc of methotrexate once a week.  That kinda sucks too, but it's nothing like the Humira was, the shot doesn't actively hurt to do; I just need to make Mari and Kye chase me around to make sure I actually take it when I'm supposed to.  

On the other hand, if methotrexate isn't the culprit... then what is?  It's not the nadolol, I weaned off then quit it for a few weeks and it made no difference.  I would laugh my ASS off if it was the Prevacid, which is supposed to make me produce less acid overall and decrease my reflux.  The folic acid is something that's naturally in the body, and I'm only taking a large supplement of it because it makes the likelihood of things like severe nausea and my hair falling out (since methorexate, Avara, and Remicade are chemotherapy agents) far less likely.  Removing the folic acid from the medley would probably increase the nausea and make me look ashen as fuck all the time.  The Flexoril is in such an extremely small dose that the doctors are boggled that it has such a dramatic effect on eradicating my "twitch," so that seems unlikely, and also, if I quit taking it, the twitch will come back and with it the full glory of my fibromyalgia.  I'll take puking my guts out on a weekly, hell, DAILY basis before I'll welcome that monster back into my body.  I doubt it's the Claratin I started taking a week ago, because I've taken it during allergy season for year with only minor headaches as a side effect.  That leaves birth control, which I also severely doubt because I've been on it for almost three years with no issues, along with Avara, which I already mentioned I suspected, and Zofran... which is the anti-nausea med that makes daily life a possibility.  

The nausea started long before Avara, however.  Those are my daily meds, but I also have an IV infusion of Remicade every four weeks; it's a TNF-blocker that stops my body from being able to form as many of the inflammation cells that are destroying my joints.  The Remicade is my real savior... it makes pain nonexistant for the first two weeks after treatment, and then it only comes back to levels that I have trouble handling in the fourth week.  I only take the narcotic painkillers when I'm in the fourth week, and only sometimes, because I can generally only hold my cookies down for about an hour after I take them.  The nausea also started before the Remicade... but before that I was on a different TNF-blocker called Humira, that I injected every two weeks... and for the record, the Humira did jack shit and hurt like hell to inject.  And, of course, the nausea started after I started it... though it was NOTHING like it is now.  

So, if it's the TNF-blocker that starts the nausea... tough shit, I can't quit.  I don't want to.  If that's what it is, I have to just live with it, the stuff is what makes me human again.  You never realize how valuable living a painfree life is until you're in hell and somebody's dangling a cup of water just out of your reach.  You just WANT it so bad, even if you're strong enough to handle life as it is.  I want to scream because I used to handle so much more than this so much better... but it's just been so LONG I've has this constant crap going on... and I got a real slap in the face for learning to ignore pain.  If I learned to ignore it all again, I suspect the fibromyalgia will come back again... and the fibro will get worse until it can't be screened out.  I'm fairly familiar with the process, and I'll take gasping over a toilet bowl every day before waking up in the morning because my entire body is screaming and I can't do anything except start sobbing.  

Just... shit, I don't know.  I see the rheumatologist tomorrow... maybe she'll make it all make sense again.  she's good at that.  I need to tell her some of the other shit that's been starting with my body in terms of major cramps and unpleasant things in that region of the body that I should have told her about MONTHS ago, because they've been getting worse... but damnit, that means more meds.  I've been TRYING playing with my diet to fix it, but it's not helping at all...  with my luck, I've gone and developed Irritable Bowel Syndrome too, just watch.  I got the fuckin' weird health LOTTERY, I tell you.  

I'm just ranting...  I can hardly wait for this next week to be over, for school to be out for a couple weeks.  I appear to have a book ready for an editor to look at, which is very happy...  Maybe I'll be published before this time next year.  That'd be a dream come true... and I'll look kickass for med school too.  I'm doing volunteer stuff this coming week too, on top of the note taking I did this semester, and a lot of volunteering in hospitals and shadowing this May... My math grades might suck, but I'll look kickass elsewise.  Locksmith (if unpracticed), published author, job at the school's disability center, thousands of shadowing and volunteering hours, graduating with close to 200 credits, along with good grades in seemingly everything except math... I should be alright.  *sighs* I just need to figure myself out healthwise... again...  

I'll feel better by tomorrow, honest.

Life is like some sort of strange dance, it seems....  when you're doing good, you're executing each step perfectly, when you're in the shitcan you're listening to the music and trying to will yourself to get back up so you can go again.... and the rest of the time you're somewhere between shuffling along and doing the steps okayish. It's not bad pain, I know I CAN ignore it.... if I can make myself care enough about what I ought to be doing to take that deep breath and start moving in the measured steps I know by heart.  I'm not scared of the destination, what comes will come... be it happiness as the disease ceases to progress, or higher doses of medication that will slaughter my immune system, or the looming lymphoma swooping down...  cancer's not that scary when you know it's coming, right?  If you watch for it, you can start treatment as early as possible, and then there's no real risk of death, despite it being a form of blood cancer... and shit, methotrexate and remicaide are chemotherapy drugs anyhow, so starting more hardcore chemo wouldn't be too much of an issue, right?  I'm used to the fevers out of nowhere that last for a few hours before fading away again, to the nausea...  I've been through enough pain that whatever might be to come should be anticlimactic, at this point.

I'm a coward these days... the pain's not bad, but I'm letting it rule me.  I used to be better than this.  What happened to the girl that said no fluke of the nervous system or disease was going to rule her life, it could all be damned, nothing was going to keep me from what I wanted. The dance seems less and less important than something of a passable shuffle.... and I've done better than this while in far worse condition.  

I need to truly care about something that I need to get done, but I do care about my school and all, I just... keep hiding behind this wall of cowardice I've built up. When I was a little girl, my parents always made sure i realized the unfortunate people in the world existed despite my privileged life.  Victims of poverty, those from abusive relationships and/or families, the unfortunate in cases of accident...  My parents were both in medicine, they understood the value of knowledge, and they showede me everything they could both good and bad so that I would have an understanding of the world.  They also instilled a deep desire to help whoever I could, whatever the situation.  

In middle school, that last got me in trouble near constantly... but I suppose that's not the point.  I always thought I was the lucky one, I was the one without problems, so I needed to be strong, stable point that anyone around me could hang onto.  By the end of middle school, I realized that a) no one wants help, b) trying to keep steady was fucking me up inside and really just making me walk on eggshells with everyone I knew, and c) it was okay to live for me too.  I wanted to help people, more than anything... but it was okay to step back and have a selfish moment too, before you burst from the pressure and shit hits the fan even harder than it did because you quit sidestepping those eggshels and started sprinting.  

Before 8th rgade really ended, I had realized that I had some physical problems.  By the time 9th was in full swing, I realized that they were really going to affect my life.  By the beginning 10th grade, I had begun to realize the meaning of true pain, and what people mean when they say pain can be disabling.  I learned to fear the sensations that told me a severe twitch fit was coming, learned to book my ass out of reality and into sleep as fast as I could when I felt my muscles start to tense even though they were already so exhausted from seizing up that i wanted to cry.
