Heh, and they thought I kept talking when I was supposed to keep my mouth shut during theater practice just because I was bored...  Everything the fan near the end of March and I finally gave in about seeing a doctor when what seemed like everything else in the world came crashing down at the same time...  I forgot my own sixteenth birthday.

After that it was series of side-effect jammed medication after medication until I finally decided to try what I'd heard about in stories, and the docs all said was impossible.  Even though it hurt like hell to do it, I learned to control that involuntary muscle movement though sheer will mixed with a fortm of self-hypnosis and relaxation techniques...  I mastered my demon.  I learned how to play with the idea of pain in my head until i could convince myself i didn't hurt, even when on some level i still wanted to scream.  If you refuse to let the pain touch you, it won't...  You just have to want it bad enough.  

Nothing could hurt me ever again.  At the same time all this was happening, I'd had an almost entirely parallel story of emotional pain, and was better for it...   I had conquered my hell, and I thought I could never be taken down again.  

I graduated a year early, and the summer leading up to my first year of college, I started getting some minor pain in my joints periodically.  I can't tell you what minor pain is anymore, but...  I think it was minor, and it didn't happen too often.  I knew rheumatoid arthritis ran in my mother's family, that most of the relatives on that side showed minor symptoms, so I didn't think much of it.... until I moved to college and it started to get worse.  I put it down as the weather; there's a good difference between Las Vegas and in the mountains in Utah.  

But then it kept getting worse.  I started taking the vitamins and supplements to help with that kind of thing...  No help.  And the pain was spreading beyond my joints.  I learned to just cope with it, it was only pain after all...  but then I screwed up my shoulders in yoga because apparently my shoulder joints are built a little oddly.  After that, it started getting worse faster, and I started to get scared.  The pain had no meaning, like the twitch muscular pain did; I knew what was happening, there.  Just, suddenly it would feel as though acid was searing down my bones, through my veins...  The slightest movement and all my joints in that limb would start popping, I limped around like an old woman, and the pain that wasn't in my joints was a million times worse, just excruciating, searing fire through every inch of my being...  I would wake up some mornings and just start sobbing.  I had mastered the pain from my twitch, learned to treat the kind of pain that would make most howl...  and now it seemed as though that awful pain was the same as when a silly child falls down and skins her knees and crying her heart out.  I was no stranger to pain, but I couldn't even begin to conquer this.  

Many tests and a rheumatologist appointment later, it was decided that I both had rheumatoid arthritis and a nasty case of fibromyalgia, the cause of which, apparently, was my brutal control over my own body.  I stressed my muscles too hard in order to manage my spasms, never let them rest enough, so they had started to steal nutrients from the rest of my body.  Bitterfuckinsweet, ne?  I do the impossible, and all I get is hell to pay.  Time to go back to the neurologist I had more or less told to go fuck himself almost a year previously, and beg for help, which came in the form of an anti-seziure med that made me twitch more than I ever had, then a test run with some muscle relaxers... which turned out to be almost as good as an on/off switch.  Then time to get nutrients back into the body I'd driven like a slave into desolation, and the pain started to ebb away in most of my body, but the arthritis became worse, and seems to be getting worse...

Seventeen is a shitty age to be diagnosed with a rheumatic disease...  though there's always worse, naturally.  The medications now are more serious, but not too hard to cope with, at least not yet.  They're destroying my immune system, bit by bit though, and... that's terrifying, really.  I'm eighteen now (finally legally responsible for my own person, woot), and it eats me away how much it hurts to use my hands most days, not even to mention any of my other assaulted joints.  I can't give blood anymore; methotrexate is a chemotherapy drug, it disrupts healing, and they don't want that.  Humira... well, the instructions include a label that says "DO NOT PUT HANDS INTO NOSE OR MOUTH PRIOR TO IMMEDIATE WASHING", so that should give you a general idea.  Some talk of being very wary of respiratory infections and how it raises your chances of getting cancer, specifically leukemia.  Then my father slaps an oximeter on me for fun and finally realizes what I've been telling him for a year, that my average heartrate when relaxing is 110-125, and now I'm on meds for that too...

It's terrifying when the pain gets to the point that you realize you would do almost anything just to make it stop.  I've been there before, the kind of blinding pain where everything is white and blurry and all you can do is flail and dimly realize that this awful noise is hurting your ears and your throat is raw but that sound won't stop...  Alternately, I've been down the avenue where you haven't stopped hurting like hell in weeks and weeks, and you're so depressed all you ever want to do is cry, because there's just no point in getting up, and your only escape is something that can steal your attention entirely, be it the company of a friend or a book or game, excitement over even the stupidest things or sex...  You just need to run away or you'll go insane and/or cry yourself back to sleep only to wake up in more pain...

*sighs* I just went to a cadaver exhibit downtown and caught myself thinking about how I'd consider giving my body to science if it weren't for the fact that my organs can be used to save someone... when it occured to me that no, actually, no one would want my organs anymore than they'd want my blood.  My best friend said something the other day that first amazed and confused me, then made me want to start crying as I thought to say that no, I wanted to do it myself... before realizing that if I'm in this much pain ON medications, what would happen if I tried to go that long without them, what a horror it would really be...  And that hurt, to realize that.  I want to be a paramedic, maybe even a doctor...  I want to save people...  but it seems like it's me who really needs to be saved.  There's so much I'm realzing I really can't do, that I'm not allowed to do anymore...  I finally got out of the house and have all the freedom of the world, legal or not...  and I couldn't take most of them up even if I wanted to.  

Shit, I'm depressed, I was hoping this might help...  It's just ironic, I always thought I was the lucky one.   Someone my age shouldn't know this much about pain...  Hell, no one should have to deal with this kind of shit, but life's never fair.  I've got so much else that's so good, maybe this is just the balance demanded of me...  it'll probably make me into a stronger person.  I remember being this depressed about the twitch, then later deciding I wouldn't want it any other way because I wouldn't be the woman I am today without that experience.  I just need to learn to cope again, I know that, and then I'll be fine.  Everything works itself out in the end, one way or another, and I'll continue on and think of my trials with this the same way I do about my past problems...  But shit, I just wish I could finish and look back already, and I guess I'm scared that it'll never truly end.  It won't ever end, not this...  but my lack of ability to cope will come to an end eventually, and I WILL be stronger for it.  That's who I am, and I'm not going to break myself over some fucking disease.
